newsitem.title: USA: Reebok sees shoe, margin pressures in '97.
newsitem.headline: Reebok sees shoe, margin pressures in '97.

text.p: Reebok International Ltd said on Thursday it expects continued pressure in its footwear sales and gross margins in 1997.

"As I've stated before, we do expect continued pressures on the sales performance of our footwear category into early 1997," chief executive Paul Fireman said in a statement with the company's third quarter results.
He indicated improvement would come when the company is able to offer a substantial number of products with its visible Hexalite, advanced DMX and 3DMF technologies at "various price points."

Worldwide sales for the Reebok brand in the 1996 third quarter were $834.8 million, a drop of 2.9 percent from 1995's third quarter. In the U.S., Reebok footwear sales were $300.8 million compared to sales of $363.1 million in the 1995 quarter, a 17.2 percent fall.
The company reported net income for the third quarter of $50.6 million, or $0.75 per share, compared to net income of $76.2 million, or $0.96 per share, a year ago.
Wall Street analysts had expected the company to report $0.80 a share, according to First Call consensus.
Reebok said its gross margin in the third quarter was 39.2 percent, up from 38.9 percent a year ago.
But Fireman said, "Looking ahead to 1997, we expect to see some pressure on gross margins as we bring our new technology products to market."
The gross margin will be pressured by start-up tooling costs, initially small production runs and increased freight charges, the company said.
Reebok said its total backlog of open customer orders to be delivered between October 1996 and March 1997 for the Reebok brand was up 6.9 percent at September 30.
